items.title: Running multiple clients throws error
items.body:
While trying to run 2 clients with 2 different API keys, I got this error
`
options = {
    "identity":{"appId":ENV_IBM_ID},
    "auth":{
    "key":ENV_IBM_AUTH_KEY,
    "token": ENV_IBM_AUTH_TOKEN
     }
}
client = wiotp.sdk.application.ApplicationClient(options)
client.connect()
client.subscribeToDeviceEvents()
client.deviceEventCallback = ...

`
When I am trying to run the second client it throws 
2020-03-25 20:48:42,216 wiotp.sdk.application.client.ApplicationClient INFO Connected successfully: XXXXX
2020-03-25 20:48:43,304 wiotp.sdk.application.client.ApplicationClient ERROR Unexpected disconnect from IBM Watson IoT


Both API keys were given the Role Backend Trusted Application.
Any suggestions that clarify why it is throwing this error? I am missing any configuration on IBM Watson IoT?

Thanks in advance.

items.title: The Connectors::create function does not pass configuration parameter to REST API
items.body:
The **create** function defined on the **Connectors** class accepts a `configuration` argument but does not use it when constructing the JSON that is passed to the REST API.

The signature for the function is as follows

    def create(self, name, type, serviceId, timezone, description, enabled, configuration=None):

The JSON created within the function for the connector is as follows:

    connector = {
        "name": name,
        "type": type,
        "description": description,
        "serviceId": serviceId,
        "timezone": timezone,
         "enabled": enabled,
    }

items.title: Unable to retrieve devices for a type using ApplicationClient / Support len() on Devices object
items.body:
I have a device type created within my Organisation and I have registered a device of that type. If I attempt to use the ApplicationClient to retrieve all of the devices of that type, I get no results back.

The code that am using is as follows:

    import wiotp.sdk.application
    
    ...
    
    self.appClient = wiotp.sdk.application.ApplicationClient(appOptions)
    results = self.appClient.registry.devicetypes[typeId].devices

items.title: Tokens with some characters in cause authentication errors
items.body: During testing in simpleDevice.py with a cfg file, an authentication issue was being returned. Everything looked fine and testing with another org and device was fine. It emerged that the bracket "(" in the token generated by IBM Cloud was the cause. I guess the way this is passed in doesn't handle special characters correctly?

items.title: Connection timeout to be increased
items.body:
Request put in to increase connection timeout from 30 seconds to 60 seconds. That way if the platform accepts the connection then it is reasonably likely it will complete or explicitly close the connection.

https://github.com/ibm-watson-iot/iot-python/blob/548d2f6a0221d69d0335ecb2e62e93bcb6ab2b75/src/wiotp/sdk/client.py#L245

items.title: AttributeError: 'ApplicationClient' object has no attribute 'ServiceBindings'
items.body: When I try to create a new cloudant service with cloudantService = appClient.serviceBindings.create(serviceBinding) I get the error AttributeError: 'ApplicationClient' object has no attribute 'ServiceBindings'

items.title: del Connector.destinations[destination.name] throws ApiException despite success
items.body:
`del Connector.destinations[destination.name]` throws `ApiException` despite successful removal of an Event Streams `Destination`.

Issue appears to be [here](https://github.com/ibm-watson-iot/iot-python/blob/548d2f6a0221d69d0335ecb2e62e93bcb6ab2b75/src/wiotp/sdk/api/dsc/destinations.py#L113); underlying API actually returns a status code of 204 for successful deletion of an Event Streams `Destination`:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32451361/63751267-eabea600-c8a6-11e9-9e5b-668779a31e94.png)

items.title: Extend psutil sample to support disk utilization
items.body:
Summary:

- [x] Learn about the psutil sample (https://developer.ibm.com/recipes/tutorials/raspberry-pi-4/) and successfully deploy it onto a Raspberry Pi
- [x] Learn about psutil capabilities: https://psutil.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
  - [x] Specifically https://psutil.readthedocs.io/en/latest/#disks
- [x] Update iotpsutil.py to add disk read and write (Kb per second) metrics to the data, use a similar calculation method to how we generate the existing network io metrics.
- [x] Verify the updated code on your local machine
- [x] Update the documentation (README.md) to cover the changes made
- [x] Commit your changes
- [x] Push your changes to GitHub
- [x] Raise a Pull Request & review with @durera 


end result should be a message format like the following:

```json
{
  "name": "foo",
  "cpu": 10.5,
  "mem": 67.34,
  "data": {
    "read": 782.34,
    "write": 84.22
  },
  "network": {
    "in": 45.56,
    "out": 673.43
  }
}
```

items.title: Schema create/update only support schema content as string
items.body:
We should support schemaContent as a string or a python dictionary, to avoid unnecessary need for user to call json.dumps() every time they use these methods:

e.g. both of these should work (from `test_api_state_schemas.py`)
```
# Update with a string
updatedSchema = self.appClient.state.draft.schemas.updateContent(
            createdSchema.id, "newEventSchema.json", json.dumps(TestSchemas.testEventSchemaUpdated)
        )

# Update with a dict
updatedSchema = self.appClient.state.draft.schemas.updateContent(
            createdSchema.id, "newEventSchema.json", TestSchemas.testEventSchemaUpdated
        )
```

```
        #self.checkSchema(updatedSchema, updated_schema_name, "eventSchema.json", TestSchemas.testEventSchema, "Test schema updated description")
        #print(existingSchema)
```

items.title: IM resources API

milestone.title: Python Client Library 1.0 Release
milestone.description: First full release of the client library.  From this point on will follow semantic versioning, limiting breaking changes to major version bumps.

items.body:
The slack conversation snippet where we discussed this API, for reference.

David Parker [2:57 PM]
to avoid a giant object that has everything baked in the approach i was looking at was one where we compartmentalise the features somewhat ... e.g.

- api.registry only has the core stuff (device types, devices)
- api.lec is where the lec stuff comes into play (e.g. rather than `registry.devices["id"].events(eventId)` it's lec.getEvent(id, eventId)
- api,mgmt (for device mgmt stuff)
- api.things
- api.whatever
what's good structure for a rest API and good structure for the python library are not necessary equal imo, hence the approach above, that I think results in a more usable library, but that's only my opinion at the end of the day.

Ian Craggs [2:59 PM]
things = things + logical interfaces for devices too?
not sure, does it make sense to seperate them to you?  I've hardly touched all the new IM apis

Ian Craggs [3:03 PM]
things build on and use the same concepts as IM device type extensions: logical interfaces and mappings, so I think it makes sense for them to be in the same ‘component’
probably

David Parker [3:03 PM]
sounds like a good starting point, if it doesn't make sense once it starts taking shape it's easy to remould the structure if needed

Ian Craggs [3:12 PM]
So in an IM component, there could be dicts of the ‘fundamental’ resources: event types, physical interfaces, logical interfaces, schemas, and then there are relationships between those fundamental resource.    So a logical interface has to refer to a schema.  A physical interface has to refer to one or more event types, each of which has to refer to a schema.

David Parker [3:15 PM]
yeah, something like:
- api.registry.devices[id] (extends defaultdict)
- api.registry.devicetypes[id] (extends defaultdict)
- api.usage (simple object)
- api.status (simple object)
- api.lec (simple object)
- api.interfaces.eventtypes[id] (extends defaultdict)
- api.interfaces.physical[id] (extends defaultdict)
- api.interfaces.logical[id] (extends defaultdict)
- api.interfaces.schemas[id] (extends defaultdict)
- api.interfaces.things[id] (extends defaultdict)
- api.interfaces.thingtypes[id] (extends defaultdict)

or, would eventtypes and schemas fit under interfaces too? (edited)

Ian Craggs [3:16 PM]
I think they should fit under interfaces - they’re not useful outside of that context, and I don’t think that’s going to change
yes, they should definitely be grouped in an interfaces module
also api.interfaces.thingtypes and api.interfaces.things
then how to capture the relationship between objects in the different dicts?
that’s pretty much the same sort of relationship between device and devicetype
which isn’t explicitly modelled in the Python API by the looks of it
(and that can be fine)

David Parker [3:30 PM]
in the library the child relationshiup is there, but trying to avoid it' becoming a total java oo representation of the data model :slightly_smiling_face:
`api.registry.devicetypes[typeId].devices[deviceId]` works and is equivalent to `api.registry.devices[clientId]`

Ian Craggs [3:35 PM]
Ok, good.  Device types in the interface world have 1) one physical interface, 2) one or more logical interfaces and 3) a set of mappings for each logical interface.  So we could have an interfaces.devicetypes which extends registry.devicetypes and adds self.physicalInterface, self.LogicalInterfaces and self.Mappings as members?

David Parker [3:38 PM]
we can put that into the registry devicetype itself as a crossover

e.g. 
api.registry.devicetypes[typeId].interfaces.physical
api.registry.devicetypes[typeId].interfaces.logical
api.registry.devicetypes[typeId].interfaces.mappings

which can function in similar way to how the listofdevices class knows how to operate in two scopes
- api.registry.devices[id] (listofdevices extends defaultdict)

- api.registry.devicetypes[id] (listofdevicetypes extends defaultdict)
- api.registry.devicetypes[id].devices[id] (listofdevices extends defaultdict) -> type scoped version of api.registry.devices
- api.registry.devicetypes[id].interfaces.logical[id] (listoflogicalinterfaces extends defaultdict) -> type scoped version of api.interfaces.physical .. actually, does this point to a single interface, or a list
- api.registry.devicetypes[id].interfaces.physical[id] (listofphysicalinterfaces extends defaultdict) -> type scoped version of api.interfaces.logical .. actually, does this point to a single interface, or a list
- api.registry.devicetypes[id].interfaces.mappings -> *what's this?*

- api.usage (simple object)

- api.status (simple object)

- api.lec (simple object)

- api.interfaces.eventtypes[id] (extends defaultdict)
- api.interfaces.physical[id] (extends defaultdict)
- api.interfaces.logical[id] (extends defaultdict)
- api.interfaces.schemas[id] (extends defaultdict)
- api.interfaces.things[id] (extends defaultdict)
- api.interfaces.thingtypes[id] (extends defaultdict) (edited)

Ian Craggs [3:43 PM]
mappings  is a JSON object which can be set on a devicetype or thingtype, for each logical interface (edited)

Ian Craggs [4:17 PM]
when is a dictionary such as Devices(api, “mytype”) populated if at all?  getitem and contains retrieve individual devices

David Parker [4:26 PM]
Under the devicetype unit.
Devices operates in two nodes based on getting the optional scope of a devicetype
If passed, it ensures that the devices object only allows access to devices of 1 type.

Ian Craggs [5:10 PM]
so can I go a = Devices(api, “mytype”) and then print(a) and expect to see all the devices of that type?  and would it get them one at a time, or all in one HTTP call?

David Parker [5:11 PM]
for device in api.registry.devicetypes[typeid].devices:
 print(device)
You don’t instantiate the devices object directly

Use it via api.registry.devices or .devicetype.devices

items.title: Client.publishEvent releases _messagesLock even if not acquired
items.body:
In `ibmiotf/application.py:377`, `_messagesLock` is acquired only if publishing was successful (`if result[0] == paho.MQTT_ERR_SUCCESS`), but it is released irrespectively in the `final:` block. This results in:

```
  File "C:\AgentWork\c2889035b7ac6605\.testenv\lib\site-packages\ibmiotf\device.py", line 307, in publishEvent
    self._messagesLock.release()
RuntimeError: release unlocked lock
```

This can happen if the client is disconnected when a message is sent (in which case paho will return `MQTT_ERR_NO_CONN`).

* This seems to have been broken accidentally as a part of https://github.com/ibm-watson-iot/iot-python/commit/ff473cead15ab9a26aa3baaea2efe1f9c8342a3c
* A simple way to reproduce this is to manually call `.disconnect()`, then call `publishEvent`.

I'm not 100% sure which code `_messagesLock` should protect; I _think_ the try-finally can be moved into the `if` statement, i.e.,

```python
                if result[0] == paho.MQTT_ERR_SUCCESS:
                    try:
                        self._messagesLock.acquire()
                        if result[1] in self._onPublishCallbacks:
                            # paho callback beat this thread so call callback inline now
                            del self._onPublishCallbacks[result[1]]
                            if on_publish is not None:
                                on_publish()
                        else:
                            # this thread beat paho callback so set up for call later
                            self._onPublishCallbacks[result[1]] = on_publish
                    finally:
                        self._messagesLock.release()
                    return True
```

items.title: Port 443 no longer supported as fallback
items.body:
Due to a restrictive firewall, we are unable to connect over port 8883, and we used the port 443 fallback for this. Unfortunately, this is no longer possible in 0.3.5:

Before connecting, the client checks whether the configured port is a supported port (`__init__.py:140`). The check requires the port to be either 1883 or 8883 (MQTT / MQTT-over-TLS). The comment at `__init__.py:131` suggests this is not intended, and port 80/443 should also work.

Changing `        elif self.port == 8883:` to `elif self.port in [443, 8883]` resolves the issue. I'm not 100% certain about accepting port 80, as this is not documented at fallback at [1].

[1] https://console.bluemix.net/docs/services/IoT/reference/security/connect_devices_apps_gw.html

items.title: Release schedule for 0.3.5
items.body:
Dear maintainers,

We ran into issue #99 recently (Cloud Support case CS0050391), and would like to switch to a version of the library with the fix (#100) included. (we're currently using a workaround where we re-setup the library every 10k messages).  Unfortunately, 0.3.5 is not released yet -- are there any plans to release it, and if so, what is the expected timeframe?

Thanks!

items.title: Support for binary and plain in http device client is half-finished

milestone.title: Python Client Library 1.0 Release
milestone.description: First full release of the client library.  From this point on will follow semantic versioning, limiting breaking changes to major version bumps.

items.body:
Reviewing the code:

We support 4 content types in HttpAbstractClient:

```
        # Default content type is json
        contentType = "application/json"
        if dataFormat == "text":
            contentType = "text/plain; charset=utf-8"
        elif dataFormat == "xml":
            contentType = "application/xml"
        elif dataFormat == "bin":
            contentType = "application/octet-stream"
```

But the device.HttpClient only registers encoder modules for xml and json, which means there's no way to actually use `plain` or `bin`:

```
        self.setMessageEncoderModule('json', jsonCodec)
        self.setMessageEncoderModule('xml', xmlCodec)
```

items.title: crash in publishEvent with data containing non-json serializable fields

milestone.title: Python Client Library 1.0 Release
milestone.description: First full release of the client library.  From this point on will follow semantic versioning, limiting breaking changes to major version bumps.

items.body:
I've been writing a custom encoder to be able to send messages to watson iot in a custom binary format.

Line 166 in device.py does json.dumps(data) before running the data through the encoder. This means that the data you send to watson must be json serializable even if you have your own encoder that does not use json at all.

This behaviour seems undesirable, there are a two fixes i can think of:

1. replace json.dumps(data) with str(data). Smallest possible fix but most objects only print "<file.class at 0x00...>"
2. move the log statement down to line 171 and log str(payload). Works for json encoders but has the same problem as point 1 for other payload types. 

If there is a consensus on the desired behaviour I will create a pull request with the fix

If in documentation reverted result: 
> If your Watson IoT Platform MQTT clients use shared subscriptions, the keep alive interval value can be set only to between 1 and 3600 seconds. If a value of 0 or a value that is greater than 3600 is requested, the Watson IoT Platform broker sets the keep alive interval to 3600 seconds.
– https://console.bluemix.net/docs/services/IoT/reference/mqtt/index.html#mqtt-keep-alive

Must be


items.title: TypeError run-time crash after publishing in a loop for a long time
items.body:
Hello,

After 64k published messages (with qos=0 and no publish call-back defined) the following error occurs and the client ceases to function:

```
Exception in thread Thread-2:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/threading.py", line 914, in _bootstrap_inner
    self.run()
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/threading.py", line 862, in run
    self._target(*self._args, **self._kwargs)
  File "/home/mike/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/paho/mqtt/client.py", line 2650, in _thread_main
    self.loop_forever(retry_first_connection=True)
  File "/home/mike/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/paho/mqtt/client.py", line 1481, in loop_forever
    rc = self.loop(timeout, max_packets)
  File "/home/mike/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/paho/mqtt/client.py", line 1019, in loop
    rc = self.loop_write(max_packets)
  File "/home/mike/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/paho/mqtt/client.py", line 1309, in loop_write
    rc = self._packet_write()
  File "/home/mike/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/paho/mqtt/client.py", line 1895, in _packet_write
    self.on_publish(self, self._userdata, packet['mid'])
  File "/home/mike/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/ibmiotf/__init__.py", line 189, in on_publish
    midOnPublish()
TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not callable
```

This is the function responsible:

```
    def on_publish(self, mosq, obj, mid):
        with self._messagesLock:
            self.messages = self.messages + 1
            if mid in self._onPublishCallbacks:
                midOnPublish = self._onPublishCallbacks.get(mid)
                del self._onPublishCallbacks[mid]
                midOnPublish()
            else:
                # record the fact that paho callback has already come through so it can be called inline
                # with the publish.
                self._onPublishCallbacks[mid] = None
```

I believe the problem here is that "mid" is a 16-bit unsigned quantity according to protocol specs, so it will wrap around after 64k "None"s have been uselessly shoved into the _onPublishCallbacks array and eventually the true branch of the condition will be taken and crash when attempting to invoke one of those "None"s..

My work-around is to simply remove the "else" branch of the condition, I see that this is trying to avoid a race condition with the publish thread, but it needs to better handle the case where no call back is defined and not grow this array to 64k entries..

items.title: RuntimeError: dictionary changed size during iteration
items.body:
I just updated to 0.3.3 and I'm getting this trackback in my application:

```
Exception in thread Thread-1:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5.2/lib/python3.5/threading.py", line 914, in _bootstrap_inner
    self.run()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5.2/lib/python3.5/threading.py", line 862, in run
    self._target(*self._args, **self._kwargs)
  File "/home/cwhitcher/venvs/python352/lib/python3.5/site-packages/paho/mqtt/client.py", line 2650, in _thread_main
    self.loop_forever(retry_first_connection=True)
  File "/home/cwhitcher/venvs/python352/lib/python3.5/site-packages/paho/mqtt/client.py", line 1481, in loop_forever
    rc = self.loop(timeout, max_packets)
  File "/home/cwhitcher/venvs/python352/lib/python3.5/site-packages/paho/mqtt/client.py", line 1003, in loop
    rc = self.loop_read(max_packets)
  File "/home/cwhitcher/venvs/python352/lib/python3.5/site-packages/paho/mqtt/client.py", line 1284, in loop_read
    rc = self._packet_read()
  File "/home/cwhitcher/venvs/python352/lib/python3.5/site-packages/paho/mqtt/client.py", line 1849, in _packet_read
    rc = self._packet_handle()
  File "/home/cwhitcher/venvs/python352/lib/python3.5/site-packages/paho/mqtt/client.py", line 2311, in _packet_handle
    return self._handle_connack()
  File "/home/cwhitcher/venvs/python352/lib/python3.5/site-packages/paho/mqtt/client.py", line 2372, in _handle_connack
    self.on_connect(self, self._userdata, flags_dict, result)
  File "/home/cwhitcher/venvs/python352/lib/python3.5/site-packages/ibmiotf/application.py", line 272, in on_connect
    for subscription in self._subscriptions:
RuntimeError: dictionary changed size during iteration
```
I think there needs to be a lock around access to self._subscriptions since it can be modified from multiple threads.

I'll try it out and report back.

items.title: missing check for duplicates when appending to _subscriptions list in application client
items.body:
Our application creates a client using iot-python/src/ibmiotf/application.py.  It then periodicallly, creates a connection and subscribes to a topic using subscribeToDeviceEvents().  (In each of these subscribe requests, the application specifices the same topic.) After receiving messages, the client is disconnected.

We are finding that on each successive call to subscribeToDeviceEvents(), additional subscribe requests are received by the MQTT server.  It looks like this is because each time subscribe() is called in subscribeToDeviceEvents(), the topic/qos for the request are added to the _subscriptions list.  It seems that before appending a given topic/qos to this list, the application client should check first to see whether the subscription is already in the list.

items.title: Delay in messages sent via publishGatewayEvent
items.body:
I'm writing a Python3 script that is meant to send messages to WIoT after it completes certain steps in a method. The problem I have is that these messages are never sent in the order I generate them and instead are sent in one big batch once my overall method completes. I believe it has something to do with the way Python handles threads. I have tried a number of ways of solving this but no success.

I understand why it's been written in a non-blocking way but equally need a method to send a message now and only continue once sent (or advice on how I should write my code so it opens up to allow the messages to be sent).

items.title: Python 3.6 - Error in paho-mqtt port type
items.body:
I'm using: 

- Python 3.6.3
- IBMIoT 0.3.1 (latest)
- paho-mqtt 1.3.1

In a RaspberryPi 3 (4.9.67-v7 latest kernel if I'm not wrong)

The problem is this:
```
Python 3.6.3 (default, Dec 14 2017, 14:47:50) 
[GCC 6.3.0 20170516] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from ibmiotf import gateway
>>> gatewayOptions = gateway.ParseConfigFile("path")
>>> rasp = gateway.Client(gatewayOptions)    
>>> rasp.connect()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/ibmiotf/__init__.py", line 135, in connect
    self.client.connect(self.address, port=self.port, keepalive=self.keepAlive)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/paho/mqtt/client.py", line 767, in connect
    self.connect_async(host, port, keepalive, bind_address)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/paho/mqtt/client.py", line 823, in connect_async
    if port <= 0:
TypeError: '<=' not supported between instances of 'str' and 'int'

```

In Python2.7 I didn't have any problem using the library.

Looking the code (from ibmiotf/\_\_init__.py), I can't see any place where the port value is different from an integer, but for some reason in client.py it's a string, not an int.

I temporally fix it casting `port` to `int` in the `self.client.connect` call in \_\_init__.py, but somewhere must be a problem either in ibmiotf or paho-mqtt

items.title: Incorrect wildcard protection for quickstart subscribes
items.body:
In application.py:

        if self._options['org'] == "quickstart" and deviceId == "+":
            self.logger.warning("QuickStart applications do not support wildcard subscription to events from all devices")
return False

However, [https://console.bluemix.net/docs/services/IoT/applications/mqtt.html#mqtt:](https://console.bluemix.net/docs/services/IoT/applications/mqtt.html#mqtt:) states that wildcard subscribes are forbidden for deviceTypes, not deviceIds.

items.title: Gateway management threads not cleaned up
items.body:
https://github.com/ibm-watson-iot/iot-python/blob/dd0451238c49c297e7c9a3b2c0f23fe5bcaa29d9/src/ibmiotf/gateway.py#L544

A new thread is started when a manage event is received (via `threading.Timer`), which is never joined/cancelled. This in turn starts a new thread without cancelling/joining the old thread, etc. This means that after running for a few days we're getting OS errors because our process has hundreds of threads and can't create any more.

items.title: Not receiving gateway commands after "Unexpected disconnect"
items.body:
### Step to reproduce
- Run the gatewaySubscribeCommand.py with valid gateway options and wait for the `Connected successfully` message
Note: Here you can send a Gateway Command. You should receive it. Everything works.
- Block the Internet connection (e.g firewall) and wait for the `Unexpected disconnect` message (>1m)
- Unblock the Internet connection and wait for the `Connected successfully` message

When we are in that state, we don't receive the Gateway Commands anymore.

items.title: Code hangs up when using on_publish callback
items.body:
I have a program which checks memory consumption of a python mqtt client while sending messages with different sizes, different qos and different amount of sending times [here](https://github.com/eifinger/paho-memory-check/blob/master/paho-memory-check.py).
I am using a callback to check if all messages have successfully been published.

My code sometimes(!) hangs up when trying to send a JSON payload of size 527 bytes with qos=1.
In sometimes I mean this either happens when I try to send this combination 10 times or the when I later try to send it again 100 times.
This code works fine when I call "publishEvent" without the callback.
While debugging I found out that [this](https://github.com/eclipse/paho.mqtt.python/blob/f53da37ce6305f4be081106c46942112465f52be/src/paho/mqtt/client.py#L1091) line in the paho lib hangs.
This happens on Windows and Linux alike.

When I attach my callback function to the paho client directly like [this](https://github.com/eifinger/paho-memory-check/blob/callbackInPahoDirectly/paho-memory-check.py)
the code again runs fine.

items.title: Unreachable code
items.body:
There are a number of if statements where code similar to the following is executed:

```
if not self.connectEvent.wait():
    self.logger.warning("Unable ... not currently connected")
    return False
```

Those log messages can never be executed and False can never be returned.  The threading.Event wait() method always returns True unless a timeout value is given and the wait times out.  Since there is no timeout, the call will always block.
* [Python2](https://docs.python.org/2/library/threading.html#event-objects)
* [Python3](https://docs.python.org/3/library/threading.html#event-objects)

Should the wait calls be modified to something like so that the connectEvent flag is checked:

```
# The number of seconds to block for the connectEvent event to be set.
CONNECT_WAIT_SEC = 0.001

if not self.connectEvent.wait(CONNECT_WAIT_SEC):
    self.logger.warning("Unable ... not currently connected")
    return False
```

items.title: Is it possible to use non-TLS connection?
items.body: It seems like this library enforce TLS connection on port 8883. Is there an option to use non-TLS port 1883?

items.title: Disk Buffering feature
items.body:
Hi,

I would like to know if the ibmiotf library can handle disk buffering ? And if it doesn't, does anyone know what would be my best alternative ?

My use-case is that I have a device that is sending logs throughout the day, if my device loses connection and get it back later on it's fine because the unsent messages are properly stored in RAM. But if the device reboots then I lose everything.

Thanks,

items.title: paho-mqtt 1.2.1 version number breaks ibmiotf library
items.body:
paho-mqtt 1.2.1 was released on 4 Apr 2017.   The version string "1.2.1" breaks the ibmiotf python library.

The error is in 
`/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ibmiotf/__init__.py`
line 105 checks for a float but 1.2.1 is no longer a float.
`    if float(get_distribution('paho-mqtt').version) < 1.1`
`ValueError: invalid literal for float(): 1.2.1`

Here's the trace
`$ python ibm-iot-quickstart.py`
`please check the format of your config file`
`please check the format of your config file`
`Configuration file found - connecting to the registered service`
`Traceback (most recent call last):`
`  File "ibm-iot-quickstart.py", line 145, in <module>`
`    deviceClient = ibmiotf.device.Client(options)`
`  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ibmiotf/device.py", line 105, in __init__`
`    port = self._options['port']`
`  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ibmiotf/__init__.py", line 105, in __init__`
`    if float(get_distribution('paho-mqtt').version) < 1.1 and`
`(sys.version_info[0] < 3 or (sys.version_info[0] == 3 and`
`sys.version_info[1] < 2)):`
`ValueError: invalid literal for float(): 1.2.1`

items.title: Type of options['port'] is error when calling ParseConfigFile()
items.body:
`def ParseConfigFile(configFilePath):
	parms = configparser.ConfigParser({"domain": "internetofthings.ibmcloud.com",
	                                   "port": "8883","clean-session": "true"})`

The type of 'port' here is `str`, but mqtt->connect need `int`

items.title: Need to call Client loop_stop when CONNECT timeout
items.body: In the connect method of __init__.py, when the TIMEOUT is reached, it just raised the EXCEPTION. however, It didn't call loop_stop to stop or clean up the thread (Note: loop_start is called few lines above).

items.title: Some devices registered successfully returned with APIException 400 RC instead of 202
items.body:
Obvious bug here:

```
		elif status == 202:
			raise ibmiotf.APIException(400, "Some devices registered successfully", r.json())
```


```
	def registerDevices(self, listOfDevices):
		"""
		Register multiple new devices, each request can contain a maximum of 512KB.
		The response body will contain the generated authentication tokens for all devices.
		You must make sure to record these tokens when processing the response.
		We are not able to retrieve lost authentication tokens
		It accepts accepts a list of devices (List of Dictionary of Devices)
		In case of failure it throws APIException
		"""
		bulkAdd = ApiClient.bulkAddUrl % (self.host )
		r = requests.post(bulkAdd, auth = self.credentials, data = json.dumps(listOfDevices), headers = {'content-type': 'application/json'}, verify=self.verify)

		status = r.status_code

		if status == 201:
			self.logger.debug("Bulk registration successful")
			return r.json()
		elif status == 202:
			raise ibmiotf.APIException(400, "Some devices registered successfully", r.json())
		elif status == 400:
			raise ibmiotf.APIException(400, "Invalid request (No body, invalid JSON, unexpected key, bad value)", r.json())
		elif status == 403:
			raise ibmiotf.APIException(403, "Maximum number of devices exceeded", r.json())
		elif status == 413:
			raise ibmiotf.APIException(413, "Request content exceeds 512KB", r.json())
		elif status == 500:
			raise ibmiotf.APIException(500, "Unexpected error", None)
		else:
			raise ibmiotf.APIException(None, "Unexpected error", None)
````

items.title: Application subscription issues
items.body:
In reviewing one of the Watson IoT Platform python scripts which uses this iot-python library, I would suggest to fix (or enhance) the current code for the followings:

- Error checking when subscribe (e.g. https://github.com/ibm-watson-iot/iot-python/blob/master/src/ibmiotf/application.py#L250 and https://github.com/ibm-watson-iot/iot-python/blob/master/src/ibmiotf/application.py#L269)

- Check before adding a new subscription to the subscriptions list (e.g. https://github.com/ibm-watson-iot/iot-python/blob/master/src/ibmiotf/application.py#L270  ) 

- Add on_subscribe callback which will be called when the broker responds to a subscribe request

items.title: Gateway subscribes to commands for _all_ devices
items.body:
On initialisation the gateway library will subscribe to commands destined for all devices, which could become an issue with thousands of commands flying around.

https://github.com/ibm-watson-iot/iot-python/blob/master/src/ibmiotf/gateway.py#L119

Would it be more reasonable to specifically subscribe to devices for commands?

items.title: httpsSupport samples are not using the new HttpClient
items.body: all the samples in httpsSupport are not using the HttpClient and so are broken.

items.title: HttpClient does not work
items.body:
('Caught exception', AttributeError("HttpClient instance has no attribute '_messageEncoderModules'",))

when attempting to use the HttpClient

items.title: Add support for play organization
items.body: Organization id parsing breaks when the play organization is used, because it is an exception to the rule that all organization IDs are 6 character strings, this prevents the library being used with that organization.

items.title: Add XML event format support
items.body:
- encode should take the data dictionary and convert to an XML string
- decode should take an XML string and convert to a python dictionary object
- register the new codec as the default handler for the "xml" format_string in the application, device & gateway clients
- extend the aplication.httpClient and device.httpClientto support json and xml formats instead of always using json.

items.title: Add suppport for command publish to application.HttpClient
items.body: It is now possible to submit commands over HTTP, add this capability to the application.HttpClient

items.title: Add support for custom MQTT port usage
items.body:
The platform allows clients to connect to alternate ports, primarily aimed at envronments where restrictive firewalls are in force.

Alternate MQTT (1883) = 80
Alternate MQTTS (8883) = 443

AbstractClient should support alt ports

items.title: Seperate HTTP publish into HTTP only client
items.body:
It's pointless having the http event publish method in a client that already has the MQTT connection.

Create a new device|application.HttpClient seperate from device|application.Client that allows a limited non-MQTT based client to be instantiated for those that wish to not use MQTT.

items.title: retrieveDevices(), getAllDevices(), getAllDeviceTypes() are still used in samples
items.body: retrieveDevices(), getAllDevices(), getAllDeviceTypes() should be removed from samples and changes accordingly

items.title: ApiClient() is not used correctly in sample files
items.body:
In sample you can find lines like

apiCli = ibmiotf.api.ApiClient(apiOptions)

should be 

apiCli = ibmiotf.api.ApiClient(apiOptions, logger)

Note: logger needs to be defined first and import the logging libraries

items.title: IoT Foundation still appear in some files
items.body:
The below files still contains reference to IoT Foundation should be replace with **IBM Watson Internet of Things Platform**

cli.py line 340 - IBM IOT Foundation
\samples\apiExamples\README.rst - Internet of Things Foundation
\samples\managedDevice\DeviceAndFirmwareActions.py - IBM Internet of Things Foundation
\samples\managedDevice\iotpsutilManaged.py - IBM Internet of Things Foundation
\samples\psutil\iotpsutil.py - IBM Internet of Things Foundation
\src\ibmiotf\api.py - IBM Internet of Things Foundation
\src\ibmiotf\device.py - IoT Foundation
\src\ibmiotf\gateway.py - IoT Foundation

items.title: historian.py should be removed
items.body: As historian was sunset as service from Watson IoT Platform is should be removed as well from here. (the code and the sample)

items.title: Samples contains IoTFCReSTException references
items.body: Samples contains IoTFCReSTException references should be changed with APIException

items.title: Response and Exception section has invalind information
items.body: IoTFCReSTException should be changed with APIException

items.title: Exception raised when `auth-method` is wrong
items.body: `authMethod` should be `auth-method` at: https://github.com/ibm-watson-iot/iot-python/blob/master/src/ibmiotf/device.py#L84

items.title: ApiClient init needs extra parameter compared to examples
items.body:
The `ApiClient` examples all use a single init variable, containing the api options, for example in `samples/apiExamples/deviceManagement.py`:

```
apiOptions = {"org": "uguhsp", "id": "myapp", "auth-method": "apikey", "auth-key": "SOME KEY", "auth-token": "SOME TOKEN"}
apiCli = ibmiotf.api.ApiClient(apiOptions)
```

On the other hand, the `ApiClient`: init definition is `__init__(self, options, logger)`, requiring an extra parameter (`logger`), in contradiction with the examples.

items.title: addDeviceType does not allow creation of gateway types
items.body:
The addDeviceType method does not allow for the creation of gateway types.  It accepts, apparently, a parameter to specify the device class.  But it sets a default value of 'Device', and then doesn't pass this parameter to the REST call anyway - at least as far as I can see.

This requires python developers to check what kind of type they want to create, and then code a separate REST call to create a gateway type.

items.title: Fail in Application Mode
items.body:
Hi!

  I made the change locally, but other error appear: Now, I can connect, but the device is connected and disconnected constantly. Can you check it?. Meanwhile I will continue using the version 0.1.8. :)

   https://github.com/ibm-messaging/iot-python/blob/master/src/ibmiotf/application.py#L229

   Regards.
   Paco Martín.

```
d:hld45t:generic2:ti-cc3200-1           Registered 153 days ago by ibmer2@in.ibm.com
d:hld45t:sdfgh:dfghgfds                 Registered 12 days ago by ibmer@uk.ibm.com
```

I suspect this is to due to API pagination design. How to work around this pagination and get full device list? 

Or this python client is useless without improving for now.

items.title: global name 'result' is not defined error while using publisher
README.txt not found
items.body:
when run "pip install iot-python.zip", there is an error complain "README.txt not found".
It's in setup.py, line 20 "long_description=open('README.txt').read(),"
